title: Erdős Problem #921: Chromatic Number and Odd Cycle Girth
description: For k ≥ 4, let f_k(n) be the largest m such that there exists an n-vertex graph with χ = k where all odd cycles have length > m. SOLVED: f_k(n) ≍ n^{1/(k-2)} by Kierstead-Szemerédi-Trotter (1984).

overview.historicalContext: A question of Erdős and Gallai about the interplay between chromatic number and odd cycle structure. Gallai proved the lower bound for k = 4 in 1963, showing graphs can have chromatic number 4 with large odd girth. Erdős proved the matching upper bound (unpublished). The full conjecture for all k ≥ 4 was resolved by Kierstead, Szemerédi, and Trotter in 1984.
overview.problemStatement: Let k ≥ 4 and let f_k(n) be the largest m such that there exists a graph on n vertices with chromatic number k in which every odd cycle has length > m. Is f_k(n) ≍ n^{1/(k-2)}?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines the function f_k(n), states the asymptotic conjecture, and presents the Kierstead-Szemerédi-Trotter theorem. The k = 4 case is shown explicitly with Gallai's lower bound and Erdős's upper bound. The exponent 1/(k-2) captures the precise trade-off between chromatic number and odd girth.
keyInsights: Higher chromatic number forces shorter odd cycles
The exponent 1/(k-2) captures the tension precisely
k = 4 gives exponent 1/2, k = 5 gives 1/3, etc.
Extremal graph theory and regularity give upper bounds

sections.title: Basic Definitions
sections.summary: Defines graph structure, chromatic number, odd cycles, odd girth, and the key function f_k(n) measuring maximum odd girth in k-chromatic graphs.

sections.title: Main Conjecture
sections.summary: Formalizes the Erdős-Gallai conjecture f_k(n) ≍ n^{1/(k-2)} and states the Kierstead-Szemerédi-Trotter theorem proving it.

sections.title: Case k = 4
sections.summary: The foundational case: Gallai's lower bound f_4(n) ≫ √n and Erdős's upper bound f_4(n) ≪ √n, showing f_4(n) ≍ √n.

sections.title: General k Case
sections.summary: The exponent formula 1/(k-2) and the general lower and upper bounds for arbitrary k ≥ 4.

sections.title: Why Odd Cycles Matter
sections.summary: Explains the connection between odd cycles and chromatic number: bipartite graphs have no odd cycles, and the chromatic/girth trade-off.

sections.title: Proof Techniques
sections.summary: Key methods: local chromatic number, Szemerédi regularity, probabilistic constructions for lower bounds, extremal arguments for upper bounds.

sections.title: Related Problems
sections.summary: Connections to girth vs chromatic number problems, Erdős's girth conjecture, and the Mycielski construction.

sections.title: Summary and Status
sections.summary: Complete summary of the problem resolution, the main theorem, and historical context from Gallai (1963) to KST (1984).

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #921 was SOLVED by Kierstead, Szemerédi, and Trotter in 1984. The answer is YES: f_k(n) ≍ n^{1/(k-2)} for all k ≥ 4. This completely characterizes the trade-off between chromatic number and odd cycle length.
conclusion.implications: The result is important for understanding how local structure (odd cycles) constrains global properties (chromatic number). The exponent formula shows the relationship is polynomial with a predictable dependence on k.
openQuestions: What are the exact constants in the asymptotic?
Can the result be extended to weighted or directed graphs?
What about other cycle parity conditions?
